 Poison all the doughnuts! I'm not sure about this one. I get what it’s trying to accomplish, and it should succeed. But there are enough bugs and glitches that it falls flat. Basically, you want to kill innocent people in creative ways. Good! Great! But 9/10 I fall back on poisoning doughnuts with "pills" and just tossing them at dudes. Basically, no NPC ever does what you want them to do, or goes were you want them to go, leaving amazingly fun traps completely useless. I had this one, I had put a sharpened stick in a pressurized valve so if I threw the switch, the pressure would push the stick out at fatal velocity. To lure an unsuspecting janitor near said trap, I threw a few cans of baked beans into two laundry machines, confident the noise would attract him. It did! And he clipped into the door and was just stuck. Reloaded and tried again. Clipped into the door again. Frustrated, I threw poisoned doughnuts at him. Get used to that. Between flammable liquid, cigarettes, exploding whatits, water jugs, endless electrical wires, sharpened sticks, collapsing ceiling fans and just good old thwacking someone in the head with a wooden beam, my most used death dealing trap as the literal son of Satan...was poisoning Crispy Crèmes and leaving them out like Elmer ♥♥♥♥ing Fud hunting a fat man. Also for a Hospital with tons of nurses, doctors and security guards, they really do move randomly! I kept trying to figure out their movement patterns, plan my murders. Nothing to it. As far as I can tell, any NPC(not locked in a room) has free range to move anywhere on the map, at any time. Making sneaking and murdering, the two core concepts of the game, rather random and difficult.I spend most of my time looking for pills to poison people, and its getting old fast. Devs, I’d recommend tightening up the AI and maybe streamlining some of the ways to kill people. Too many tight corners you can’t throw things past, and too many small rooms where its impossible to throw cans at ceiling fans without being noticed and the unsuspecting victim standing up and the fan missing.EDIT: Okay, I'm offically calling this game done. Found a beach ball randomly in a hosptial. When I highlighted it, this is what I got: "Bengt the ball is the name given by Pewdiepie to the red and white ball found in Game Lucius 1"So, buy at your own risk...

												Lucius II is a GREAT game. The plot makes sense, there's a decent amount of content and replayability, it's a beautifully atmospheric game and it stands alone in its style. All in all, I'd give this game an 8/10. What Lucius II tries to achieve, it achieves fairly effectively. There's a few bugs and problems, but considering the enormity of the game, it's to be expected, and none of the bugs are particularly ground-breaking.Personally I'd price it at around $15, so grab it at a discount if you can. However, the developers seem really committed to updating and patching Lucius II, and the game definitely has a unique style to it (that I for one love). If you'd like to see a Lucius III, I definitely would say that you won't be too disappointed paying full price for the game, and you'll help contribute to a sequel :)I've broken down my review into positives, slight negatives and big negatives as follows. I'd weigh up each of the following before deciding if you'd like to buy the game or not:POSITIVES:- Much more content to explore than the original game! The hospital ward plus the town of Ludlow total roughly three times the size of the mansion in the original!- A controllable and customisable level-up system - choose how to progress your skills!- SO much customisation and interactability with the environment. You can combine some items with other items to create complex traps for potential victims, as well as use some items with objects in the environment for the victims to interact with.- A plethora of ways to kill victims. The original game was incredibly limited, but in Lucius II you'll never be short of potential ways to hunt your victims down!- Due to the number of ways to kill victims, replayability is definitely an option!- Full and working controller support! No more mapping keys to buttons!- Achievements that were much more thought out than in the original: certain hours of gameplay and travelling specific distances are a thing of the past!- Collectibles that you can hunt down!SLIGHT NEGATIVES:- A nitpick, but there are both spelling and grammar errors in both the subtitles and the in-game descriptions (while playing in English). The audio sometimes is slightly different to the subtitles.- I encountered a few objects or items that simply said '[TEXT DESCRIPTION]', so I'm guessing the developers forgot to code in some of the text. This doesn't affect functionality in any way.- For whatever reason, when I started up, the default subtitle size was set to 0.0 instead of 1.0, so I couldn't even read the subtitles at first. I don't know if this is hard-coded into the game, or specific to me, but for a professional game this shouldn't be a problem.- The first level is next to impossible to kill everyone in for the 'Problem Child' achievement due to an extremely limited number of potential ways to kill the mental patients.- There's a few glitches. Occasionally you'll come across a door that doesn't open, but you simply pass through. Occasionally electricity or a cord will take on a mind and physics of its own, though this doesn't affect gameplay at all, just the visuals.BIG NEGATIVES:- KEYS. I love the concept of gathering keys to unlock areas, but there's a serious problem with them. Occasionally, they'll disappear once you reload a save without collecting them. If you save over your original save, there's no way to get them back, and you are sometimes left unable to complete a level. Considering this game relies a lot of save-and-load, you're bound to run into this at least once.- While the total area you can explore is indeed more than in Lucius, the areas are *entirely* level-specific. In the original, it was always the same mansion, perhaps with slightly more areas available each level. In Lucius II, each level is independent.- Serious kill-mechanic oversights. There's so many brilliant ways to kill victims, but I found myself not even hunting them out, as every level after the first is far too EASY. This is mostly due to Mind Control regenerating power on a successful kill, and an over-powered item. I've summarised these in spoilers for you, in case you don't want to read about the 'easy kills':Once you unlock mind control, you can basically get every single person in the first chapter to simply walk down an elevator shaft. The developers limited the number of times you can do this (which was a great idea), but they forgot about fire. Kill someone with fire, then mind-control another victim and have them walk over the first victim's burning corpse. The second victim will die, and also catch on fire. This fire lasts around a minute, and resets the timer if you kill another victim. I managed to pile up over 30 victims from the result of one initial flame!The nailgun is over-powered. One shot is an instant kill, and it comes with 5 shots per pack of nails. There's even a second pack of nails right by the gun when you first find it, giving you 10 shots. If that's not enough, at the start of chapter 2 there's another 15 nails for you to collect, giving a total of 25 possible kills from the nailgun alone.

												That's what I call a disappointment!After a first episode, mediocre in execution but faithful at heart to the sub-genre of psycho kids movies, Lucius II could've been a great improvement to a really cool concept and a nice niche game. The linearity of the first episode? Gone! You have freedom to use your environment, and to compose with your habilities to create the kills you want. The lack of indication and sometimes really hard to figure puzzles? Gone too! Everything is written, sometimes three times (you know, just in case you were wondering if that door was a door...well it is!), you have plenty of informations and a map that moves in real time to help you out. The colision and AI bugs? Ghhu...oh wait. That's where it starts to stink.Because let's face it, Lucius II is a really poorly executed concept, a buggy mess, and a non-polished game that would deserve the "early access" tag at best.First of all, there is absolutly no AI. The characters react without any logical sense. You just killed someone with a gas explosion in a room? Don't worry about being detected, the person in the next room won't even hear what the hell just happened. You want to lure someone with the noise of an object? Good luck with that. The NPCs won't hear a thing half the time, and the rest of the time, will just stand there in awe, with a question mark on there head. They will continue there activities with a deceased body in the same room, covered with acid, or even with electrical wires coming down from the roof. Simply put, they don't give ****.And it's not like if it was the only "oversight". Nope, the controls are aweful. It not in the way Lucius moves, but in every aspect of the interaction with the game. Lucius can't grab anything with his hands: he has to use telekynetic powers to grab anything. It doesn't drain your energy, BUT if you go anywhere near a christian cross, the object falls on the ground and the little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ can't pick it up, because he can't use telekynetic power in range of a cross. Oh sure, you can grab another object and throw it to the cross to flip it, but that's anoying. Now the biggest problem with that stupid idea of not being able to just grab something is this: if you have any object out of your magical pocket (you know, the one that contains 250 lbs worth of objects), you are suspicious: meaning you can't walk around with anything in your hand and you constantly have to holster in and out anything you want to use. Worst! Let's say you want to push a trolley with gas tank on it, to set it on fire and blow someone up, well since Lucius is allergic to everything, you can't push the thing if someone is around, because...you're pushing it with your mind and that's pretty suspicious. Bottom line, you can't touch anything, and that's pretty stupid.And at this point, you maybe thinking "well if the AI sucks, how is that a problem?" Well it's problem because IT BREAKS THE IMMERSION THE CHALLENGE THE MECHANICS THE GAMEPLAY THE ENTIRE FREAKING POINT OF THE GAME. Why would you play a game that consist in killing people in plain sight, without being seen, that has no AI what so ever, and that stops you from using the fun part of the levels? It's tedious, stupid, broken as hell (in the last two chapters, most NPCs died without me even being in the same room) and un-polished like an alpha from a Bethesda game. Sometimes object go through walls, preventing you from grabbing them; when it's a key, well you can load the level entirely. The ragdoll is out of controll, like Dark Souls on crack; when someone dies, anything can happen with the body. The worst thing about it is, that's the least of your problems when you play the game.As much as I liked the first one (with its flaws), and as much as I wanted a sequel, to get the Hitman X Omen that the first one made me wish for, I just feel like I've been abused by the developers. If you read me: I know you don't have that much money. I know you meant well, but that's not how you treat the players. If you don't have money for a good looking 3D game (yeah I didn't even mentioned the fact that it looks dated and that the background are atrocious) of that scale and that ambitious, you don't do it. You have to be cleverer and make better choices in term of technology and game-design. Why chose a hospital, a really crowded place, when you know, you absolutly know, that the AI is incapable of even reacting to the sound of an explosion? Why do you chose a wide open town, with corn fields that can't hide anything, if you are not capable of doing a good matte-painting? And seriously, what the hell is with all this indications everywhere? The concept is really cool, and GOD I wish there was someone to actually pull this off (like IO Interactive...the one from Blood Money, not Absolution) and make it a good game, while keeping the corniness of the plot, characters, and background that, in my opinion, add to the charm of the game...but yeah, that's not it. At all. And no patch can fix most of the problems.Don't buy. PS: the soundtrack is really nice though...but the audio mix sucks :'(

												Lucius 2 begins at the end of Lucius 1. The detective saves you from the burning house, you end up in a hospital, here you attack a nun, get thrown into isolation and kill your doctors. here starts the actual gameplay, where you have to escape the hospital. Pros: +Lots of ways to kill people, you are no longer restrained to kill a person the same way. this might seem like only 1 + point, but this has great impact on your game experience and will make you wanna play more than 1 playthrough as you can take a different path now.+more maps, and bigger. there are like 10 maps, and each has lots of people in it (especially the maps in the hospital and in the town)+ More abilities, tree perk. you no longer only have 1 or 2 abilities you can use like in lucius. we were only able to create fire in the last few moments of the game, so you could max kill 3 people with the most awesome abilty.. however, in lucius 2 because of the tree perks you can decide what abilities you want first, (there are 3 tree perks, each has a few more powers in it as you level it up, you can have 2 full tree's when you complete the game)+Graphics are slightly better, but this doesnt matter that much for most people.now lets talk cons.-Lucius 2 has a bad story, this is something everyone can agree on. the beginning makes sense and is alright. but as you move forward, and complete the town map, you get the feeling they just send you to random blunt maps which seem the same and kinda boring looking-its hard to understand at first. before the game begins you get this little tutorial which gives you lots of information in a few minutes, which you quickly forget as some powers you wont immediately use. in lucius 1 the powers were evenly spread and when you got a new power / ability it was clearly explained how to use it and when, this however was not the case in lucius 2. (i had to look up a guide for the first map, so i understood how i could do everything and where to look for hints etc.)-the people in this game are absolutely ridiculous. you can kill someone in front of a nurse and she wont even come of her chair. you can break/modify items and people staring at you wont stop you. the only way to make them move is to actually walk in a restricted area, and even then is their line of sight really bad so you dont ever have the feeling of being truly ♥♥♥♥ed. also when you do get busted you can just use a lifeline and go on again, youll lose a bit of health but its easily gained by visiting a toilet (which are everywhere in this game)Okay, lets get real here for a second: Lucius 2 does not exceed the expectations after playing Lucius 1 for alot of people, the story is worse, AI is terrible, the people react bad, but that doesnt mean that this is such a bad game. Lucius 2 is a fun game to cycle around with your tricycle as you kill people with anything that you can touch. (or mind control) it might not be the most realistic or serious game but thats okay. Cause its fun.Id rate this game a 7/10 for enjoyment. as its really original with its playstyle. you wont often play something thats like this. i do recommend buying this on sale though. since the worth of the game really depends on what you find important in a game.

												Sequel to Lucius, the game where you control son of the Devil and try to kill people. In this one story continues right after the first game. Detective takes you away from the mansion, you are placed into the hospital for medical treatment and psychological evaluation. But things get out of hand when medical staff start to poke you with nasty medicine.You pretty much go ham on the whole hospital staff and patients if you wish of course, you don't have to kill everyone, but who am I kidding. Liquids have different properties, some ignite if you add flame, others conduct electricity or are great way to trip someone if you pour it near some dangerous hazards.Few of the ways to send someone packing: Smash some electricity panel and expose the wires, pour some water from the canister and throw sandwich in it to lure some enemy for a shocking death. Drop some pills in coffee machine and brew coffee, then wait for unsuspecting nurse to taste the hot cup of sweet poison. Break open the elevator controls, open the elevator doors, then empty some oil or washing gel near the shaft, add some lure and voila a slippery drop to their death. You can also simply throw a bottle with flammable liquid under someone and then ignite with one of your powers for a quick fiery death. Throw acidic bottle in someone's face or break a valve on steam pipe, strap a sex toy on it (no kidding) and let it go for unsuspecting shower accident.Combinations are endless, there's a lot more ways to add more souls to your collection just explore the level and don't rush with the killings. It's a short, fun game with not as interesting story as the first game, but much more unleashed in terms of gameplay.There's no vsync option in game, and if there is it's not working, so what I did is I limited the framerate through the RivaTuner Server, which is part of MSI Afterburner. Sure it's not needed if you want 300 fps in the game but GPU is starting to melt with such high fps on my end.Anyways, have fun and enjoy.

												The main reason why I'm recommending the game is not because I adored the first, but because it has quite a lot of promise despite it's flaws. The plot of the story is just as basic as the first, but tries to over complicate itself with themes and character development that is lackluster and could have been slowed down for a more meaningful experience. Some moments, like when you first physically meet with Lucifer and when you meet up with your demon brother Isaac, leaves much to be desired. The story is rushed and feels as if, despite the gameplay and world being much more thought out, the story was put on the backburner and not given as much attention as it deserved. The story had very redeeming qualities that if it was given more time and effort, it would have been a lot more exciting. I really loved the idea of Lucifers sons fighting to be the favourite and doing so through a biblical demonic event. It moves past the personal struggles with his biological family and makes his demonic one more dynamic and almost human. For the gameplay, I felt that the fast paced and almost rushed qualities of the story rubbed off on it. The skills you obtain and the different ways that you can execute your targets were plentiful. You didn't have individual targets like the first game though, but whole floors full of people with you having a choice whether to only kill those you need to kill, or to kill them all to get more power. This is great, but the first games targets felt a lot more personal and gave you a chance to have an attachment to the character if you so wished to. If there would be a better balance between each aspect of the game and slowed it down, I think it would be much more successful of a game. Also, in regards to the endings hint towards a Lucius 3, it was a good ending at best and would have benefited with a little more flare. Perhaps using that tutorial map more so Lucifer could have more of a spotlight like he had in the first game would have done the trick. In my opinion I'd give the game a solid 6/10.

												I honestly enjoy it more than the original Lucius. Sure the voice acting isn't as good, sure there are bugs, but the good stuff is just so good.While the cutscenes in the first game are satisfying, getting to plan your own murders is a ton of fun. It also gives the game more replay value than its predecessor, since in that one it kind of loses its touch once you know how to beat every stage. I also adore the new skill tree system and the abilities to choose from. Especially since it doesn't force you to specialize yourself; as long as you kill enough people in every stage, you can probably max out the skill tree. And still, it sure is fun to play through the game with different play styles. Wanna start off as a mind controlling puppetmaster? Do that! Wanna become a master of telekinesis and toss people around? Do that! Wanna watch stuff burn? Do that!Even though the game still steers your actions through the objectives, it still allows great freedom. Personally I'd love to see some kind of sandbox mode where you can choose between different locations to wreak havoc upon. The graphics have improved as well, so now I can finally look at Lucius's face without wanting to return to staring at the back of his head. The climax was also more impressive this time. It didn't just make you feel like an epic badass, it made you feel like an epic badass fighting a stronger epic badass. And that was fun.Which leads me to one of my few complaints (spoiler alert): I'm not a fan of Isaac. Mostly because of his voice. A character like him who appears to be obsessed with the prophecy and talks the way he does should have a psychotic kid voice to go with that. But instead he was given a really ordinary low-pitched evil voice. Same with the devil. What was wrong with his old voice? I really liked that one.But overall it's a really fun game, expecially if you like to get creative and watch people die. Don't expect to get "Lucius, but even more" because you won't. This game is very different from the previous one, and to me in a good way.I really, really hope they make a third game. And if that isn't enough to finish the storyline, a fourth. And a fifth. And a sixth. And as many as the developers deem neccessary. If they keep this up, I promise I will continue playing them.

												Lucius 2, sequel to Lucius. In this game, you control Lucius, the son of the Devil. Your objective is to go around and kill people, for the glory of Satan of course. You're meant to use your environment as a tool to kill nurses, patients and other people. When you kill someone, you need to hide the bodies. Otherwise people will find them and grow suspicious and panicky. Now, as a game, the concept is very creative and fun. Who does not want to go around and use the supernatural to kill your foes? However the game seems to fall a bit on the matter of actual functionality. The game is riddled with bugs and glitches. The organs and arteries spilled in the beginning was an ASTOUNDING touch and I absolutely loved the start of the game where you walk around the ward in a straight jacket covered in blood. It made the whole setting all the more exciting and interesting! It was a sad day when you had to go find and put your suit back on. :( Back in black, baby!The story was even more interesting than the first game's. Instead of following a storyline of murdering people in the house in specific ways and in certain orders, you were able to freely roam because it's a sandbox game, and you do whatever as you please, when you please, how you please. Although some tasks of murdering people in certain ways were tedious, near the end of the game I would just mind control people (who were either in the way of what I needed to do or had something on them that I needed) and simply make them walk into a fire I started or was already there lol. I know, how uncreative of me. What I'm getting at here is that some ways of murdering were tougher than others, but I'd rather spend an extra 3-5 minutes figuring out how to kill someone in a creative way rather than just poisoning their coffee or donuts or something. 												I really wanted to like Lucius II -- I love the idea of setting devious traps for the unwary, and the unique story certainly has a lot of potential. However, there are so many game-breaking bugs, poorly designed interfaces, performance issues, and control scheme nightmares that I cannot recommend this game to anyone.For example, there is a sequence where Lucius must use a shotgun. Simple, right? No. The process goes like this:1. Collect the shotgun and shells by aiming the reticule at them, pressing E, and then pressing G (yes, really).2. Go to the inventory screen and drag the shells onto the shotgun. The game does not pause while you're in this window, despite the fact that you can't see any of the action, so it's very likely you'll get mercilessly ravaged while you attempt to do this.3. Double-click the shotgun to equip it. Urghh, it didn't work. Double-click again. Double-cli- Oh, there it goes.4. Fire twice before having to repeat the clumsy process all over again.Additionally, it's possible to get into states where a level becomes uncompletable -- for example, on many of the hospital floors, there are keys you need to pick up in order to progress. These keys can disappear or become lodged somewhere out of sight, and the level has to be restarted.There's a fair amount of slowdown in this game, which is odd considering the fact that the graphics aren't anything to write home about. The final battle is particularly bad about this -- particle effects grind the game to a halt. Expect freezes, too.There's a great number of smaller issues that the developers surely must have noticed -- for example, the inventory screen often claims containers are 100% full when they're actually empty, volume levels fluctuate at random from scene to scene, and when Lucius drops objects, they hover in midair instead of falling to the ground.Add to that the fact that no one proofread any of the text, and you can clearly see that this is another half-baked Unity game released on Steam far too early. I hope that Lucius II becomes playable someday, but for now, it's impossible to justify spending $20 for the dubious pleasure of playing this frustrating game. Overall, it's a great concept, but it feels like it's still in alpha.

												I just... no. Not something I found enjoyment in playing.I purchased this game soley because  Cr1TiKaL voiced one of the characters  in the game. But after playing with the intent of personally interacting with the character, I just gave up; the game was just that unenjoyable.At first, I thought the game concept was kind of interesting and creative. As I was playing the game it, at first, seemed to have a nice atmosphere and setting. But everything went downhill after the cutscene with the demon and the investigator. All seriousness was sucked out of my experience when that demon's mouth moved in such a cartoonic fashion. And things did not get better once the actual gameplay started.The tutorial was a bit lazy. Takes you to hell so you can learn how to play. Why couldn't it take place in the actual world? And learn as you complete the first mission? That's something that's pretty much standard these days. Anyway, after getting out of hell and starting the real game, things become pretty tedious feeling. It's already been mentioned in other reviews but there doesn't seem much of a point to some of the creative ways to kill people except for fun. So why do that when you can just poison all the doughnuts?The one positive thing I found in the game was a reference to Kitty Forman from That 70's Show.As for the story, I feel it's a bit poorly written. It feels like the story was an after thought or the story came after the they already had the idea for where they want Lucius to go, like it was just tagged on.Lastly, I could not get past the terribly handled "easter egg"/tribute to PewDiePie. I'm not a fan of the guy, and I don't have a problem with him, but the way the whole beachball thing was handled is just painful, like being beaten over the head with a sack of frozen oranges. Expect with oranges you aren't out $20 and you can still uses them for something. I'm sure maybe it made some PewDiePie fans giggle a little, but for the rest of us it made an already disappointing experience even worse. The only thing I can imagine that would have made it any worse would be if the ball talked and was voiced by PewDiePie himself. Or by Fred.In conclusion, this game was just a let down and I advise those who are curious about this game take a moment and reconsider purchasing this game.

												After being in the Psych Ward for six months, the doctors decide shock treatment is the best for young Lucius and that’s where things go wrong. Sadly, you don’t get to see what happens next but judging by the blood on the walls and the dead body sitting next to you with the deliberator in his chest one can only imagine…Unlike the first game where each person has a specific way they need to be sent to Hell, the sequel gives you the chance to explore the possibilities with a wide variety of deaths ranging from poisons, explosions, mind control murders, and flying oxygen tanks that are almost impossible to aim. My favorite kills so far have to be combining water on the floor with the deliberator, and using the nail gain which is pretty much a one-shot kill for each nail you have at your disposal. The hardest kill method is the oxygen tanks I’ve mentioned, because there’s no easy way to aim the sucks on the cart they use and the item keeps moving after you’ve stopped moving the cart. I could kill with a Dixie cup and some string easier than the tanks.So far I’ve found an exploit; each of the deliberators can only be used once but saving and loading back to such saved file will reload the deliberator for use again, as well as tone down some of the way people look at you when it comes to suspicion – by the way you might be missing an item or two or need to do an objective again but that’s a small price to pay if it means you can essentially use a kill method near-indefinitely.There’s a lot of things I like about this game but many of them are also things I liked about the first as well – such as the exploration, the music, and the immersion. Playing as the son of Satan is great and since he has no lines of any kind he doesn’t bore anyone with quotes cheesy one-liners. There’s a quote from Highlander in this one – imagine how much I laughed.But there’s still some things that I didn’t like that returned as well. The music does seem to lag out from time to time and the voice narration is super quiet. Although the objectives are really clear, the kill methods seem to have some preferred victims, making it hard to kill that person with the keys if you’ve already used up your poisoned doughnuts.The only two characters returning from the first game are the detective – the narrator but replaced with a different voice actor from the first – and Lucius’ human father but his role in the sequel can be summed up and being a vegetable on a hospital bed next to a life support machine than can be shut off at any time. That’s about it.In short, I like Lucius 2 and will stand by the game in all its glory and faults just like I did its predecessor. I’m a little ways into chapter two and it doesn’t seem to have a very long game by the looks of it. According to Steam, there’s only about four more missions before the game is complete, but replay value is pretty high – there’s boggle heads to collect, kills to try out, skills to obtain, and cars to get hit by, so I can see myself playing this one for a while.Now if you’ll excuse me I just reduced the population of Ludlow to zero and must explore to see if I missed something. To those playing this game, happy hunting!(Fun fact: The town of Ludlow seems to have gotten in adult gizmos that are available at the General Store.)

												I'm not sure exactly why everyone is hating on this game. Personally I enjoyed every minute of it and will continue playing long after I have finished. There are only a few games in my entire Steam library that I have actually sat down and played from beginning to end; and fewer still that I actually go back to. With most games I usually get bored after awhile and start playing something else, but Lucius II kept me thorougly entertained during my entire playthrough. Yes it is a short game, but each level is a sandbox that provides unlimited diversion. Yes, there are bugs, but I have not encountered any that were gamebreaking. I only crashed once in the many hours I've played, and the other bugs I encountered were mostly minor, such as a missing icon or broken camera angle when climbing up to a rooftop.I have only a few gripes, and nothing too serious to keep anyone from enjoying this game. The first is a lack of kill animations. Whenever you sucessfully kill an NPC they will usually turn into a ragdoll and fall on the floor. The kills are still interesting and unique and should delight most players, but the lack of detailed death animations kinda makes that elaborate setup you worked so hard on seem disappointing. Another problem is the AI in general. It still needs a lot of work. Sometimes an NPC will get stuck in a position or have trouble reacting to the bait you left on the floor, or sometimes they will just sit in mid air. They also do not react when an explosion just rocked the next room. This brings me to my final complaint which is the overall unpolished feel to the game. As players have suggested, it feels rushed. You'll notice a decline in quality as soon as you watch the cutscenes, which are nothing more than paper dolls with a character narrating. I don't know if they were going for an aesthetic appeal with this or just cutting costs. When compared to the cinematic cutscenes of the first game it really feels like they opted for the less expensive route.Personally I'm not bothered by the cheap changes or the small bugs and beta AI, but now I cannot decide which game I prefer. I love the first game, and that one actually feels like a finished product, but the lack of variety really turns me off. After you finish that game there's really no reason to go back to it unless you are achievement hunting. Lucius II, however, lets you plan your murders, set up traps, and kill in any order. On the other hand, in Lucius I the kill scenes were so gruesomely gratifying. It's really hard to decide which game is better, but I think that once the devs finally iron out all the problems in Lucius II I'm sure most fans will be happy with it. There's an amazing sequel to Lucius here, you just have to dig through all the mess to find it.(Oh yeah, and the final boss is a direct replica of Malachai from Children of the Corn. Too awesome!)
